instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3332: What is 820-3332? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> mux
threads.message:
No liquid, no impact, no visibles.

No internal display, ran ASD reports MUX IG internal switch error.

I wonder if the issue could be A1 <SIGNAL>GPU_SEL</SIGNAL> not pulling low?.... Or if it's something else I have no idea about?.. Or just a fucked chip?

What is the likely cause and solution please?

Thank you.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> mux
threads.message: My blame would be on the mux first and foremost. You can use a regular SMC stencil to reball one from a donor

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> mux
threads.message: So external video works?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> mux
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 20140"]So external video works?[/QUOTE]

Yes external works and no internal is detected and ASD says mux is not switching.

[QUOTE="larossmann, post: 20132"]My blame would be on the mux first and foremost. You can use a regular SMC stencil to reball one from a donor[/QUOTE]

Thanks, I'll give it a go.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> mux
threads.message: <CHIP>U9150</CHIP> is a very simple analog MUX and ASD has no way to tell if it switched or not besides not seeing an LCD. My guess this would be an LCD/connector/eDP caps problem.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> mux
threads.message: eDP cap missing should give displayport symbol error in ASD. Weird.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> mux
threads.message: In that case I'll just try everything I possibly can starting from the screen and working back.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> mux
threads.message:
[QUOTE="larossmann, post: 20132"]My blame would be on the mux first and foremost. You can use a regular SMC stencil to reball one from a donor[/QUOTE]

Pitch and ball size is different. What stencil can I use for this?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> mux
threads.message:
I still don't believe the MUX is the issue. All caps in edp lines checked? Tried a known good LCD? 
Reballing would require a universal 0.5mm pitch stencil. A COMPLETE PITA

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> mux
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 20314"]I still don't believe the MUX is the issue. All caps in edp lines checked? Tried a known good LCD?
Reballing would require a universal 0.5mm pitch stencil. A COMPLETE PITA[/QUOTE]

You may very well be right but I pulled the mux off already so now I need to stck it back on and it may aswell be a new / donor one.

From LCD connector the side I have Tested:

New LCD cable on old screen.
Known working screen.
New LCD connector.
All of the DP_INT_ etc, caps
<SIGNAL>LCD_HDP</SIGNAL>

Not tested:

<SIGNAL>LCD_FSS</SIGNAL> - not sure what that even does and the datasheet for <CHIP>U9100</CHIP> is fucking mind boggling.
Likely I have not tested lots more I should have before I went pulling the analog mux.

Will test all, again, once some donor 3332 boards arrive.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> mux
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 20314"]I still don't believe the MUX is the issue. All caps in edp lines checked? Tried a known good LCD?
Reballing would require a universal 0.5mm pitch stencil. A COMPLETE PITA[/QUOTE]

You were of course completely correct. I've stuck the new mux back on now and it's the same.
Got a good screen in there too. Side from just replacing everything I'm clueless.

What do you think guys, please?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> mux
threads.message: So I have now replaced every cap conected to the LCD connector, stuck a good screen on it, replaced screen connector, replaced <CHIP>U9150</CHIP> and <CHIP>U9100</CHIP>, checked all inductors.... I have no fucking idea what to look for.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> mux
threads.message: This is a good one. If you have a donor board, you may as well replace the inductors. Testing these for continuity in high speed data circuits isn't the best way to measure these.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> mux
threads.message:
[QUOTE="Gurmon, post: 20823"]This is a good one. If you have a donor board, you may as well replace the inductors. Testing these for continuity in high speed data circuits isn't the best way to measure these.
[/QUOTE]

Good point, but no change :-(

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> mux
threads.message: No idea now. Other than a broken/corroded trace somewhere, what else can it be.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> mux
threads.message: Did you verify the basics like power at L9000? Should be at least a short burst of power there after turning it on.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> mux
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 20878"]Did you verify the basics like power at L9000? Should be at least a short burst of power there after turning it on.[/QUOTE]

Yes, 5.4V and stays on.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> mux
threads.message:
Uhm, that means the LCD is recognized and should at least do something......
Voltage on backlight pin?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> mux
threads.message: backlight is 0V... Now I know what you are going to say but the [B]OS does not know the internal screen is there. ASD reports GPU mux switching error and a light through the Apple shows nothing[/B]. And I have a working screen on there. What the fuck is going on here?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> mux
threads.message: I'm out of ideas besides <CHIP>U9100</CHIP> or the GPU itself.
